entry.title: SAP PPM Certification Ends Dec 2025?
entry.content:
Dear All,

I've just came across the information that, SAP is about to discontinue the SAP PPM Certification (C_S4PPM_2021) upon ending Dec 2025 as per attached screenshot, and for alternative certification, SAP is recommending the Certification in SAP PS module (C_TS412_2021).

So, my question is, the person who has earned the SAP PPM Certification mentioned above or already scheduled its exam to be passed, what would be his position even if he already hold the Certification of SAP PS (C_TS412_2021).

Please guide at your earliest.

Also guide, what will be the future certification recommendation for SAP Consultants who will hold or already have experience in SAP PPM or SAP EPPM?

If there is any other new Certification for SAP PPM or SAP EPPM on SAP S/4 Hana, please guide.

 

 

Please note that, this person already have some practice based experience (not a live project) for SAP PPM.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Investment WBS Settlement Option in SAP...
entry.content:
Good day @Tirukanagouda_K 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer is, no. However, I will explain the reason below.

To summarise, the public cloud does not support cross company settlement when Asset Accounting is involved. Investment WBS, AuC and final asset must be attached to the same company code. This is also confirmed in KBA 3456675. You can find the detail here: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3456675

That means, there is no standard option to perform an intercompany settlement between investment WBS elements before or instead of asset transfer.

My recommendation is to:

  • Settle the investment project in company code A to AuC and final asset.
  • Use Intercompany Asset Transfer within same country (1IH) to move the asset between your company codes. Below you will find more details on Scope Item 1IH

https://help.sap.com/docs/help/979ee481d97045cb8857e3fac1d0073f/84f72ee1fda946dd8667c4a33171ff52.html?locale=en-US

Should you at anytime need earlier intercompany allocation, your usual design separate investment projects in each company code and use intercompany billing or internal charging, while you keep settlement itself strictly intra company.

This Blog provides some very useful insights: Settlement of Investment Projects in SAP Cloud ERP

You may also refer to this on how to run Settlment for Actual: 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/65511a912abd45518fdab7d995304e47.html?locale=en-US

Let me know if you have more questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Semantic search in CAP (Node.js): vector embeddings and cosine similarity
entry.content:
In this blog post I report on my recent experiments and findings on how to implement a semantic search in CAP Node.js. The goal for the search mechanism was to be able to find the item in an entity with the best semantic match based on a user query (prompt). This can be achieved using (local) vector embeddings and a cosine similarity search. I was pleasantly surprised how easy it is to handle vector embeddings locally without the need for an actual (vector) database (at least when not considering scaling).

While watching the Devtoberfest 2025 session on Agentic Coding with CAP by David Kunz, I was intrigued to inspect the source code of the CAP mcp-server that was talked about. Turns out, the search_docs tool of the server is implemented using vector embeddings and a cosine similarity search. This sparked my interest to explore this topic further and see how the concept can be applied to other scenarios as well.

To start off, I will give you my understanding of vector embeddings (which might not be scientifically accurate, but is sufficient for applying the concept): Vector embeddings are numerical representations of data. Each vector has a lot of dimensions and a numerical value for each of the dimensions. The number of dimensions depends on the embedding model used. Data that has similar meaning, let's say "banana" and "apple", will also be closer to each other in the dimensional space than "banana" and "computer". It is important to note that you can only compare vectors that were created using the same embedding model, as a comparison requires the same number of dimensions with the same meaning. To create vector embeddings in a (CAP) Node.js application, this is all we need:

import { pipeline } from "@xenova/transformers"
const embedder = await pipeline("feature-extraction", "Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2")

const data = [
    {
        text: "banana"
    },
    {
        text: "apple"
    }
]

const createEmbeddings = async () => {
    for (const item of data) {
        const embedding = await embedder(item.text, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        item.embedding = JSON.stringify(Array.from(embedding.data))
    }
    return data
}

console.log(await createEmbeddings()) // [{ text: 'banana', embedding: '[-0.057455405592918396,0.03617725893855095 ...

Going back to the original quest of implementing a semantic search, the next step is to compare the vector embedding of a user query with the vector embeddings of the existing items. For that, we use a cosine similarity search. The cosine similarity is a measure that calculates the cosine of the angle between two vectors in a multi-dimensional space. The result is a value between -1 and 1, where 1 means the vectors are identical, 0 means there is no similarity, and -1 means they are completely opposite. The principle here is that vectors that have a smaller angle between them (are closer to each other) are more similar in meaning. This concept is fundamental to how large-language models work. To calculate the cosine similarity between two vectors, we can use the following code:

// see code sample above for creating embeddings

import cosineSimilarity from "cosine-similarity"

const search = "computer"
const searchEmbedding = await embedder(search, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
const results = data.map(item => ({
    text: item.text,
    similarity: cosineSimilarity(Array.from(searchEmbedding.data), JSON.parse(item.embedding)).toFixed(4)
}))
console.log(results) // [ { text: 'banana', similarity: '0.4076' }, { text: 'apple', similarity: '0.5369' } ]

The cosine-similarity module essentially does all the heavy lifting for us. After creating the embedding for the search ("computer"), we compare it with each of the existing embeddings to get a similarity score. The higher the score, the similar the data is in meaning. As we can the in the logged result, "computer" is more similar to "apple" (0.5369) than to "banana" (0.4076) - for obvious reasons.

The next step is to integrate this search mechanism into a CAP application. I create a simple CAP service with a Products entity, that also exposed a semanticSearch function. In the handler for that function, we create the same logic as shown in the code sample above. The only difference is that we now fetch the existing items from the database (embeddings stored a string) and return the items sorted by their similarity to the search term. It is important to note that we create the embeddings not in the actual search handler, but during the initialization of the service - for obvious performance reasons.

import { pipeline } from "@xenova/transformers"
import cosineSimilarity from "cosine-similarity"

export default async function catalog() {
    const products = this.entities["Products"]
    const data = await SELECT.from(products)
    const embedder = await pipeline("feature-extraction", "Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2")
    for (const item of data) {
        const embedding = await embedder(item.text, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        await UPDATE(products, item.ID).with({ embedding: embedding.data })
    }

    this.on("semanticSearch", async (req) => {
        const { search } = req.data
        const data = await SELECT.from(products)
        let results
        const searchEmbedding = await embedder(search, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        results = data.map(item => ({
            ...item,
            similarity: cosineSimilarity(Array.from(searchEmbedding.data), JSON.parse(item.embedding))
        }))
        results.sort((a, b) => b.similarity - a.similarity)
        for (const result of results) {
            delete result.embedding
        }
        return results
    })
}

Please note that this sample won't scale for large datasets, as we are loading all items into memory for the search. Also, we are storing the embeddings in the database as strings, which is not ideal. For larger datasets, a vector database like SAP HANA Cloud would be more appropriate. However, for smaller applications or testing/learning purposes, this approach should work fine.

We can now test this semantic search by calling http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/semanticSearch(search='computer'), which returns the following data:

{
    "@odata.context": "$metadata#Products",
        "value": [
            {
                "ID": 1,
                "text": "apple",
                "similarity": 0.5369198543970098
            },
            {
                "ID": 2,
                "text": "banana",
                "similarity": 0.40761179144643095
            }
        ]
}

Now let's the if customers would find the banane if they searched for /semanticSearch(search='yellow fruit with curved shape'):

{
    "@odata.context": "$metadata#Products",
        "value": [
            {
                "ID": 2,
                "text": "banana",
                "similarity": 0.40374334839388043
            },
            {
                "ID": 1,
                "text": "apple",
                "similarity": 0.2445011304736103
            }
        ]
}

And that's how we can implement a true semantic search in a CAP Node.js application! I was pleasantly surprised how easy it is to create and handle vector embeddings locally without the need for an actual vector database (at least for smaller datasets). Also, we didn't need to rely on any external APIs to large-language models or the like, the embedding model runs completely locally.

I hope you like this and maybe learned something new - I certainly did.

entry.title: Collective Value Helps in RAP: V2 and V4 Implementation Guide - Part 2
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, we explored the fundamentals of Collective Value Helps in RAP, covering implementation patterns across OData V2 and V4 service bindings. The community response has been overwhelming, with particular interest in hierarchical implementations for complex business scenarios.

While CDS hierarchies are extensively documented in the SAP ecosystem and widely used for representing parent-child relationships across business objects, a critical implementation gap exists: there are virtually no practical examples of incorporating hierarchical display patterns within Collective Value Helps. Part 2 bridges this gap by demonstrating how to seamlessly integrate hierarchical search templates into the collective value help framework we built in Part 1.

Watch the demonstration video below to see hierarchical value helps in action, including how they work alongside existing flat list search templates, in a Collective Value Help:


System Requirements

**Hierarchical Value Help Dialogs require: **

**SAP S/4HANA Cloud**
--Minimum Release: 2311
--Protocol: OData V4 service binding

**SAP S/4HANA On-Premise/Private Edition: **
--Minimum Release : S/4HANA 2025 onwards
--Protocol: OData V4 service binding

**Important: ** OData V2 does not support hierarchical visualization out of the box via CDS Hierarchy due to protocol limitations. CDS hierarchical patterns require OData V4.

CDS Hierarchies: Foundation for Hierarchical Value Helps

CDS (Core Data Services) hierarchies are well-established patterns in the SAP landscape for representing parent-child relationships. SAP provides comprehensive documentation and numerous community resources for learning hierarchy fundamentals:

  • Hierarchy Definition | SAP Help Portal
  • Treeviews with Read-Only Capabilities | SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Community: CDS Hierarchy Articles

This article focuses specifically on utilizing CDS hierarchies within RAP-compliant value helps and demonstrating how to incorporate hierarchical search templates alongside the flat templates created in Part 1.

Key Use Case: Hierarchies are particularly powerful in domains like Asset Management, where technical objects form complex parent-child structures that users need to navigate when making selections.

Business Context: Asset Management-> Hierarchical Relationships

In Asset Management, technical objects naturally form hierarchical structures that reflect real-world installations and organizational relationships:

Functional Location Hierarchies:

  • Parent functional locations contain child functional locations
  • Example: TATM â†’ TATM-UT3 â†’ TATM-UT3-001
  • Represents physical plant structure and organizational grouping

Equipment Hierarchies:

  • Equipment can be installed under functional locations
  • Equipment can be installed under other equipment (sub-assemblies)
  • Example: Main equipment (11947458) contains sub-equipment (11947627)

Mixed Hierarchies:

  • Equipment installed at functional locations
  • Sub-equipment installed under main equipment
  • Creates complex parent-child navigation requirements

A sample Hierarchy in Asset Management:

Transaction: IH01 - Structure List

Why Hierarchical Value Helps Matter:

When users select technical objects in business processes (work orders, maintenance notifications, asset transfers), they need to:

  • Understand the installation hierarchy
  • Navigate parent-child relationships visually
  • Select objects while seeing their organizational context
  • Identify relationships between equipment and functional locations

Standard flat list value helps lose this critical hierarchical context, making object selection difficult and error-prone in complex asset structures.

Implementation: Building the Hierarchical VDM Model

Step 1: Interface View (I-View) with Parent Association

The foundation of any CDS hierarchy is a self-association that establishes the parent-child relationship.

I-View

Critical Elements:

  • Self-Association _ParentNode: Establishes the many-to-one parent relationship
  • Cardinality [0..1]: Each node has either zero (root) or one parent
  • Join Condition: Links child's SuperiorTechnicalObject to parent's TechnicalObject

This I-View serves as the data foundation, providing the parent-child relationship that the hierarchy view will consume.

Step 2: Hierarchy View Definition

The hierarchy view transforms the I-View's parent association into an actual hierarchical structure with defined traversal rules.

Hierarchy View

Critical Hierarchy Annotations:

  1. source ZAR_I_TechObjHierarchy: References the I-View containing the parent association
  2. child to parent association _ParentNode: Specifies which association defines the hierarchy
  3. start where SuperiorTechnicalObject is initial: Defines root nodes (no parent = top of hierarchy)
  4. siblings order by TechnicalObject: Sorts nodes at the same level
  5. multiple parents not allowed: Enforces strict tree structure (each node has max one parent)

This hierarchy view establishes the traversal logic and structural rules for displaying the parent-child relationships.

 

Step 3: Consumption (C-View) Definition 

The consumption view serves as the bridge between the CDS hierarchy and the collective value help framework. It exposes the hierarchy as a searchable value help provider while maintaining the hierarchical data structure.

C-View

Critical Annotations:

  1. @ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities
    #VALUE_HELP_PROVIDER: Enables this view to provide value help data
    #SEARCHABLE_ENTITY: Allows search functionality within the value help dialog
    These capabilities are essential for user interaction
  2. @odata.hierarchy.recursiveHierarchy: [{ entity.name: 'ZAR_I_TechObjHierarchyView' }]
    THE CRITICAL HIERARCHICAL LINK
    Note: The entity name should reference the Hierarchy View (from Step 2), not the I-View or C-View itself.
    Points to the CDS hierarchy view created in Step 2
    Instructs OData V4 service to use hierarchical structure
    Without this annotation, hierarchy won't display in value help
  3. association of many to one ... as _ParentNode
    Recreates the parent association in the consumption layer
    Must match the join conditions from the I-View
    Required for OData V4 hierarchy metadata generation
    Links both TechnicalObject AND TechObjIsEquipOrFuncnLoc (composite key)


Step 4: Including Hierarchical Template in Collective Value Help

Now we integrate the hierarchical search template into our existing collective value help framework from Part 1:

CVH V2 Metadata Extension

CVH V4 Metadata Extension

Service Definition

OData V2 Service Binding: The Limitation

Service Binding OData V2

This eliminates the possibility of incorporating hierarchical search templates via CDS hierarchy in V2 collective value helps. OData V2's protocol limitations prevent hierarchy visualization in value help dialogs


OData V4 Service Binding: The Solution Path

Service Binding OData V4

The V4 service binding successfully exposes the hierarchical template without errors.


The Problem - Flat List Display

Even with a properly defined hierarchy view exposed in V4, the initial preview reveals an unexpected result:

Flat List Display (as opposed to expected Hierarchical display)


The Problem:
Despite having a hierarchical CDS view, the value help displays data as a flat list without any parent-child visualization. Users see individual records but lose all hierarchical context.

Why This Happens:
Creating a CDS hierarchy view is necessary but not sufficient for hierarchical display in value helps. The RAP framework requires explicit UI presentation instructions to render hierarchy in the value help dialog.

The Missing Piece: The framework needs explicit instructions via presentation variant annotations to understand that this data should be rendered as a hierarchy tree, not a flat table. Without these annotations, OData V4 treats the hierarchy view as just another data source.

The Solution - Presentation Variant Annotations
To provision hierarchical display in value helps, we must add specific presentation variant annotations that declare hierarchical visualization intent.

Consumption View (C-View) Annotations

C-View (Presentation Variant Added)

A presentation variant annotation needs to be included here which will contain the InitialExpansionLevel for the hierarchy and  a property RecursiveHierarchyQualifier.

RecursiveHierarchyQualifier - This annotation contains a string with the name of the hierarchy view and make possible that the data is then shown on UI as tree table. The projection view should also have the annotation

InitialExpansionLevel - This annotation indicates up to which level a display hierarchy shall be initially expanded.

Collective Value Help Metadata Extension

CVH V4 Metadata Extension (Presentation Variant annotation added)

A presentationVariantQualifier annotation needs to be included here, which should've the same value as the Qualifier in the C-View, i.e., 'HIERARCHY', in this case. This annotation indicates how the value help result should be displayed.

The Result: Hierarchical Value Help in Action

Hierarchical value help display

Success! The hierarchical variant now displays:

  • Parent-child relationships visualized as tree structure
  • Expand/collapse controls for navigation
  • Indentation showing hierarchy levels
  • Seamless integration with flat templates from Part 1
  • Full hierarchy traversal in value help dialog

User Experience - End Users can now:

  • Switch between flat and hierarchical search templates
  • Navigate parent-child relationships visually
  • Expand/collapse hierarchy nodes and even the entire Tree View
  • Select objects while understanding their organizational context
  • See equipment installation hierarchies and functional location structures

Key Takeaways: When to Use Hierarchical Collective Value Helps

Use Hierarchical Patterns When:

  • Parent-Child Relationships Matter: Business objects naturally form hierarchies (org structures, location hierarchies etc)
  • Context Aids Selection: Users need to see relationships to make correct selections
  • Navigation is Important: Users need to browse up/down hierarchies during selection
  • OData V4 is Available: V2 protocol does not support hierarchy visualization

Implementation Checklist:

  • Define I-View with self-association (_ParentNode)
  • Create hierarchy view with traversal rules (start where, siblings order by)
  • Use OData V4 service binding (V2 not supported)
  • Add presentation variant in C-View
  • Reference presentation variant in CVH metadata extension
  • Test expand/collapse and hierarchy navigation

Key Implementation points:

  • Cardinality Enforcement: multiple parents not allowed ensures tree structure
  • Root Node Definition: start where clause correctly identifies top-level nodes
  • Presentation Variant annotation must be added in C-View and CVH metadata
  • Qualifier Consistency: Same qualifier in C-View and CVH metadata


Series Conclusion
This two-part series has explored the complete spectrum of collective value helps in RAP:
Part 1 established the foundation:

  1. Basic collective value help concepts and structure
  2. Implementation across OData V2 and V4 service bindings
  3. Service binding architectural differences
  4. Nested value help workarounds
  5. Multi-dimensional search capabilities

Part 2 extended to advanced patterns:

  1. Hierarchical CDS view construction
  2. VDM model for hierarchy-enabled value helps
  3. OData V2 protocol limitations
  4. Presentation variant configuration for hierarchy visualization
  5. Seamless integration of flat and hierarchical search templates

Together, these patterns enable user-centric, multi-criteria search capabilities that leverage RAP's full value help framework while maintaining clean architectural separation and reusability.

Key Architectural Insight:
Collective value helps in RAP provide a powerful, user-centric approach to value help management by enabling multi-criteria search through a single, reusable model. The addition of hierarchical display patterns extends this capability to complex business scenarios requiring parent-child navigationâ€”delivering a comprehensive search experience that adapts to diverse user needs.

Conclusion
Hierarchical collective value helps represent the convergence of RAP's value help framework with CDS hierarchy capabilities, enabling rich, context-aware search experiences for complex business objects. While implementation requires careful attention to presentation variant configuration and V4 protocol requirements, the result is a powerful pattern applicable across any SAP domain where parent-child relationships drive user decision-making.
Whether you're building asset management applications, organizational hierarchies, material master navigation, or any scenario requiring hierarchical context during selection, this pattern provides the foundation for delivering intuitive, efficient user experiences.
The combination of CDS hierarchies, collective value helps, and RAP's presentation variant framework creates a powerful combination for solving complex data selection challenges-no custom coding required, just optimal usage of key annotations.
Thank you for following this two-part series. I welcome your feedback, and experiences implementing collective value helps in your own RAP applications.

entry.title: MM_Classification or serial numbers

entry.title: Re: How to set trigger for Integration Suite for periodic...
entry.content:
Hi @taao19710316 ,

In SAP Integration Suite, the standard timer event does not support an arbitrary list of dates (like holidays) out-of-the-box. It is designed to run on a repetitive schedule, e.g., defined days of the week or month.

For your use caseâ€”triggering an iFlow periodically while excluding national or company holidaysâ€”a two-step approach is recommended:

  1. Use the standard timer for the base schedule

    • Configure the timer to run on the relevant weekdays (e.g., Mondayâ€“Friday).

    • This handles the majority of your scheduling needs (roughly 80%).

  2. Filter out holidays using externalized parameters and Groovy scripting

    • Maintain a configurable parameter (e.g., in the Integration Flowâ€™s properties) containing all holiday dates. The dates can be comma-separated in a consistent format, such as US date format or your company standard.

    • Add a Groovy script at the start of the iFlow that checks the current run date against this holiday list.

    • If the date matches a holiday, the script can stop further execution; otherwise, processing continues as usual.

This approach allows the iFlow to run on all weekdays but only process data on valid business days, and it keeps the solution flexible. You can update the holiday list for the next yearâ€”or even several years aheadâ€”without modifying the interface design

entry.title: Re: Restricting Company Code Access in Run Statutory Repo...
entry.content:
Good day @Prasit_Arpornrat 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4de200b26d5d42bbacae69c6bf6b9923/fb15635742dced74e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

In summary, run Statutory Reports does not offer a standalone setting in the app to restrict company code. The system relies on your organisation units for example your company code, which are then merged into reporting entities, authorisation and team responsibility checks. See: Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting for some insights.

There are some reasons why the desired restrictions when running reports does not work in your case. Some of those are:

  • Yor report category does not use company code as an organisational unit, or
  • Maybe the users you intend to restrict still have broader access, which was given to them through other roles, or
  • The intended user is assigned to some reporting entities that group several company codes.

In reference to those potential causes, you can achieve the restriction by:

  1. Ensuring the company code is used as an organisation unit in your statutory reporting and it is correctly assigned to reporting entities.
  2. Check the intended Userâ€™s business roles and restrict company code as desired.
  3. I advice you use Manage Teams and Responsibilities so that each user is only responsible for reporting entities that match their company code.

Some users may still see more values in the company code but they will only get tasks and can only run reports for the company codes you have authorised.

This link guides you through the statutory report: https://cdnapisec.kaltura.com/html5/html5lib/v2.101/mwEmbedFrame.php/p/1921661/uiconf_id/37285991/entry_id/0_oswzfw8h?wid=_1921661&iframeembed=true&playerId=kaltura_player&entry_id=0_oswzfw8h

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: An error occurred during message processing and no re...
entry.content:
Hi @sakshi_tekale 

Your retry is not triggered because the Exception Subprocess ends with an Escalation End Event, which marks the error as handled.
In JMS-backed delivery assurance, retries only occur when the error is unhandled and propagates back to the runtime.

To enable retries, you must either:

  • remove the Escalation End Event,

  • replace it with an Error End Event,

  • or rethrow the exception inside your subprocess.

Once the exception is allowed to reach the JMS adapter, CPI will automatically retry based on your JMS delivery assurance configuration.

entry.title: Whatâ€™s New for the SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Integration
entry.content:
The 2025.11 release brought further enhancements to the integration between SAP Fieldglass and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). This integration allows Configuration Manager users to customize approval, and now workflow logic with a self-service, no-code solution.

Whatâ€™s New for the SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Integration:

  • BTP Business Rules Payload Configuration Enhancements

The BTP Business Rules Payload Configuration interface has been enhanced to support front-end validation with a new business rule type: Workflow.  This option improves the accuracy and flexibility of rule setup by allowing users to validate both native SAP Fieldglass fields and Custom Fields based on the chosen business logic.

When submitting a Job Posting, users now select External Validation and will receive a Success, Warning, or Error message depending on the Decision Table setup in SBPA.

  • Enhanced Custom Field Support for BTP Integration

The Base Module in the BTP Business Rules Payload tile in SAP Fieldglass already supports Custom Fields and Linked Modules. With the 2025.11 release, there is now the capability to include all Linked Module Custom Fields. Extending this capability to all transactional child modules aligns the system to the business needs by leveraging Custom Fields across all relevant modules.

  • Previous Revision Supported in BTP Business Rules Payload

A Previous Revision section has been added to the configuration interface in SAP Fieldglass to allow comparison between current and previous document revisions in approval logic. This eliminates unnecessary approvals, accelerates document processing, and reduces manual intervention.

Want to Learn More?

  • The SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Approval Integration video shows step-by-step how to setup the integration between SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA.
  • Watch the new Integrating SAP Fieldglass with SAP BTP SBPA for Workflow On-Page Validations video for a detailed overview of the new Workflow business rule type.
  • Explore the Integrating SAP Fieldglass with SAP BTP SBPA Guide for more information on the benefits, workflows, use cases, and links to additional enablement resources.

entry.title: The Managerâ€™s Guide to a Successful Performance Cycle
entry.content:
A great performance cycle isnâ€™t just about filling formsâ€”itâ€™s about creating clarity, accountability, and growth. Based on the HR Business Practices, one of the key assets of the SAP SuccessFactors process library, here are the essential actions managers should take at each stage of the cycle.

  • Setting Goals
  • Translate business strategy into team and individual goals aligned with corporate objectives.
  • Explain how performance outcomes influence rewards and opportunities.
  • Set goals and attributes according to the defined cycle and rating logic.
  • Continuous Updates
  • Keep goals, reviews, and development actions current and evidence-based.
  • Hold regular check-ins and coaching conversations focused on progress and support.
  • Provide timely, specific feedback linked to goals and attributes.
  • Encourage employees to request feedback and capture achievements.
  • Use self-service tools to document goals, feedback, and progress throughout the year.
  • Adjust goals and workload based on continuous insights.
  • Performance Review
  • Use formal reviews to summarize ongoing dialogueâ€”not start from scratch.
  • Prepare evidence-based performance cases ahead of calibration.
  • Seek HR support only for exceptions or complex situations.
  • Calibration
  • Participate actively in calibration sessions and be open to challenge and adjustment.
  • Apply agreed calibration outcomes consistently in reward and talent decisions.
  • Share feedback on calibration formats with HR.
  • Follow-Up Actions
  • Communicate decisions and next steps clearly and fairly to employees.
  • Provide feedback to HR on where the process supports or hinders real performance dialogue.

Why It Matters:
Managers are the driving force behind performance success. By following these recommendations, you turn the performance cycle into a strategic advantage for your team and the business.

Coming Soon:
Stay tuned! A new version of the HR Business Practices will soon be available. Check out this page for deeper insights into HR functions and how they support organizations in driving success.

entry.title: You Are Standing in an Open Field... Inside SAP GUI
entry.content:
How I ported Zork to ABAP in one day and made 46-year reunion of two mainframe legends possible.

1979 was quite a year for the mainframe: In Germany, SAP released R/2, the integrated ERP system that would define enterprise computing. In Massachusetts, Infocom was founded to commercialize Zork, the text adventure born on MIT's PDP-10 mainframes.

For 46 years, they ran on parallel tracks. Until last month.

Microsoft released the original source code for Zork I. The stars aligned. It was time for a family reunion.

I got nostalgic. I wanted to play Zork I: The Great Underground Empire. But I didn't want to play it in a browser or a terminal. I wanted to play it where I spend my time: In SAP GUI.

So, I decided to port the Z-Machine (Infocom's Virtual Machine) into SAP S/4HANA.

The Z-Namespace destiny... you knew it. In SAP development, every custom object must start with the letter Z: (Also Y, but Y is not used widely. And no one knows why Y is not used)

  • The Machine: Z-Machine.
  • The Transaction: ZORK.
  • The Package: $ZORK.

So it felt like it was meant to be here.

Building a VM in One Day (The "How")

"Alice," you say, "Writing a Virtual Machine in ABAP takes weeks of reading bit-level specs."

It took one day.

And I wrote almost none of it:

 
ZORK T-CODE in SAP GUI

99% Vibe coded

I used VSP (Vibing-Steampunk) â€” my open-source bridge that gives Claude (or Copilot/Codex/Mistral Vibe - any other Assistant) direct access to the SAP system via MCP. I treated the AI not as a chatbot, but as a Senior ABAP Developer who loves retro specs.

Here is what happened when my Z-Machine crashed on the first turn:

Me: "It crashes when I try to LOOK. Plz debug."

Claude didn't guess. Using VSP, Claude:

 

  1. Set a breakpoint in the ABAP code.
  2. Ran the game inside SAP.
  3. Inspected the memory (finding a Big-Endian vs Little-Endian mismatch in the object table).
  4. Fixed the code.

 

This isn't just generating text. This is Digital Archaeology assisted by Artificial Intelligence.

Why This Matters

I now have Zork running in S/4HANA.

But the real story isn't the game. It's the capability.

If an AI agent can read a 1980s technical spec, navigate a custom ABAP stack, and debug runtime errors to reunite two pieces of 1979 history...

...imagine what it can do for your 2005 legacy code ^_^ (Yes, even with ECC).

  • The Repo (ZORK-ABAP): https://github.com/oisee/zork-abap
  • The Tool (VSP): https://github.com/oisee/vibing-steampunk - ADT-to-MCP bridge.

Credits:

  • Infocom (1979) for the Z-Machine.
  • SAP (1979) for the R/2 legacy that led us here.
  • Graham Nelson for the Z-Machine Standards Document.
  • Claude (2025) for writing the code.

entry.title: Re: Clear down payment at the time of billing in S/4HANA...
entry.content:
To clear an open incoming payment which was not automatically closed, the app Clear Incoming Payments can be used to clear a receivable payment manually, such as an open incoming payment for a customer invoice. The system usually clears these payments automatically. However, sometimes customer information is missing, and the system cannot find appropriate open items that match the payment.

You can find more information on this in the Help Documentation: Clear Incoming Payments | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Unit of Measure Mapping in Document and Re...
entry.content:
Hello @JuanseVal 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Have a look at this Blog: eDocument Colombia Cloud Initial Configuration

1. Answer to question regarding how you should handle SAP UoMs like PI when DIAN has no direct piece code:

For you to send PI as such in the XML, it must be in the DIAN catalogue. Which means you need to, map PI to a valid DIAN unit code that represents a single unit. This is typically a generic unit code used i your DIAN list. This practically means:

  • You keep using PI in logistics and sales,
  • You should convert your PI to the DIAN generic unit code. Therefore, quantities in the XML will remain the same but the unit code will change.

Here is a reference for configuring Unit of Measure (UNIT_OF_MEASURE): https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/cb9131e59ba34741923bd19ef4cb1f90/c8b16ee10e194b2880600db594a1e1c9.html?locale=en-US

2. Answer to your question regarding the availability of an SAP standard mapping table for Colombia:

To my knowledge no such mapping of SAP UoM Ã  DIAN UoM exist. The documents provided only explain how you can configure Unit of Measure in the App. Reason is the diversity of customers with various business cases and conversions.

3. Answer to your question regarding the creation of custom mappings:

You can, infact you must create custom value mappings for your use case (Colombia). While it is standard that you maintain your own lines in UoM for Colombia, the constraint worth noting is that the external value must be a valid DIAN code. Else the validator will reject the XML. So, you have two real options:

  • Option A is to keep SAP UoM and map to the closest DIAN unit, where you keep PI and other units for logistics, map each internal unit to DIAN legal code and use material UOM for conversions.
  • Option B is to adapt your business units to DIAN units, where you change sales UoM in the material master to match DIAN codes. This reduces mapping complexity but has a bigger impact on your processes and reporting.

4. Finally, my recommendation and experience is to:

  • Use DIAN unit list
  • Map you operational units where the exact label does not exist
  • Make sure you use description field and product master text to keep things clear
  • And finally, only adapt materials UoMs if the difference is material for taxes or pricing.

What this basically confirms is that your idea of handling PI through value mapping is in line with the Colombian implementation as long as you choose DIAN legal code.

Find below some more useful links

Electronic Customer Invoices: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/88d44bce214447bcb7cbbdc03eb16aa1/e7876c954f804f83add892c5ab660a39.html?locale=en-US

3432505 - eDocument Colombia Cloud Troubleshooting Guide: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3432505

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Fiori Elements: Dialog and busy indicator issues with actions
entry.content:
CAP application with a Fiori Elements front-end:
I've setup an action which opens a dialog box and accepts 'inputText' as input.

     @CDS.odata.bindingParameter.name: 'worksOrder'
      @Common.SideEffects: { TargetProperties: ['to_SearchResults','to_SearchFeedback','to_WorksOrderItems']}
      @ui.OperationAvailable: true
      @ui.Importance: #High
      @ui.OperationGrouping: #ChangeSet
      action getSearchResults(
        worksOrder: $self,
        @Core.Required
        @Common.Label: 'Describe in your own words what part you are looking for?'
        @ui.MultiLineText : true
        inputText: String(100)
      ) returns Boolean;

This calls a method, which perform a number of await methods, and finally returns true, closing the dialog.

The issue is, the first time it's executed, the busy indicator shows, and disables the dialog so it can't be closed. After the first time, the dialog is active (can be closed), but the busy indicator is now behind the the dialog, and can't be seen.

Ideally, the UI would be better if the dialog would auto-close, showing the busy indicator until the method has completed, in all cases. I don't want to return out of the action method early, as I have side-effects setup which means I need to manually refresh the data after the call.

Does anyone have a solution for this?

entry.title: Re: Identity Provisioning Service(IPS)-Assigning Custom Attributes to IAS Users with Transformation
entry.content:
@antoniobkw the following code worked for us to add SuccessFactors custom attribute 2. In our case, we needed to split users into SSO vs Password login based on whether they were Salaried or Hourly respectively. Therefore our Custom 11 field, which holds the Employment Type in SF is brought over to IAS like this:

{
"sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11']",
"optional": true,
"targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['value']"
},
{
"condition": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11'] EMPTY false",
"constant": "customAttribute2",
"targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['name']"
},

Further on in the Target Transformation, the following code was added to assign them to the SSO group ID in IAS:

{
"condition": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11'] == 'Salaried Exempt'",
"constant": [
{
"id": "0207511c-7f9a-4297-9807-xxxxx"
}
],
"targetVariable": "assignGroup"
},

entry.title: HANA-Powered AMDP CRUD Framework: A Complete Workflow from ADT Development to ABAP Execution
entry.content:
1.Introduction 

In modern SAP applications, performance-critical database operations can be executed directly in SAP HANA using AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures). This approach allows complex CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations to be processed efficiently in HANA while keeping the ABAP code clean and maintainable. In this guide, we explain how to implement a full CRUD solution using an AMDP class (ZCRUD_PROCEDURE) and consume it from an ABAP report with Data Base object. 

By the end, you will understand: 

  • How to design an AMDP class for CRUD operations 
  • How to call AMDP methods from ABAP 
  • How to handle different modes: Read, Update, Create, Delete 
  • How to display results or messages to users 

2.Business Requirement 

A business user needs to manage order data stored in the custom table ZCDS_CRUD. The requirements include: 

  1. Read: Display existing records in display-only mode. 
  2. Update: Pre-fill existing records and allow editing of fields. 
  3. Create: Insert new records with input from the user. 
  4. Delete: Remove a record and display a success/failure message. 
  5. Performance: All operations should execute directly on HANA using AMDP for speed. 

To achieve this, we implement: 

  • An AMDP class containing HANA SQL Script logic for all CRUD operations. 
  • An ABAP report that interacts with the AMDP class and provides an interactive interface for users. 

3.Technical Components 

  • ABAP Class (AMDP): ZCRUD_PROCEDURE 
  • Interface: IF_AMDP_MARKER_HDB 
  • Methods: READ_DATA, READ_ALL_DATA, INSERT_DATA, UPDATE_DATA, DELETE_DATA 
  • SQLScript logic for CRUD directly on HANA 
  • ABAP Report: ZCRUD_REPORT_AMDP 
  • Selection screen for input fields and CRUD mode checkboxes 
  • Calls AMDP methods 
  • Handles display, editable fields, empty fields for creation, and delete confirmation 

4.Application Flow 

  1. User opens report ZCRUD_REPORT_AMDP. 
  2. User enters an Order Number (P_ORD) and optionally Item, UOM, Quantity. 
  3. User selects one or more operation modes: Read, Create, Update, Delete. 
  4. Report calls AMDP class methods depending on the selected mode. 
  • Read: 
  • Calls READ_DATA 
  • Displays record in display-only format 
  • Update: 
  • Calls READ_DATA to fetch record 
  • Prefills fields with existing data 
  • Updates using UPDATE_DATA 
  • Create: 
  • Uses empty or input fields to call INSERT_DATA 
  • Delete: 
  • Calls DELETE_DATA 
  • Displays success/failure message 

5.Key Logic Implementation 

5.1 AMDP Class Definition 

CLASS zcrud_procedure DEFINITION 
  PUBLIC 
  FINAL 
  CREATE PUBLIC. 
 
PUBLIC SECTION. 
  TYPES: tt_type TYPE TABLE OF zcds_crud. 
  INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS read_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
    EXPORTING VALUE(it_data) TYPE tt_type. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS read_all_data 
    EXPORTING VALUE(it_data) TYPE tt_type. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS insert_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
              VALUE(iv_item)  TYPE zcds_crud-item_number 
              VALUE(iv_uom)   TYPE zcds_crud-uom 
              VALUE(iv_qty)   TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS update_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
              VALUE(iv_item)  TYPE zcds_crud-item_number 
              VALUE(iv_uom)   TYPE zcds_crud-uom 
              VALUE(iv_qty)   TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS delete_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number. 
 
ENDCLASS.

5.2 AMDP Method Implementations (SQL Script) 

CLASS zcrud_procedure IMPLEMENTATION. 
 
METHOD read_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  it_data = SELECT * FROM zcds_crud WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD read_all_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  it_data = SELECT * FROM zcds_crud; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD insert_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  INSERT INTO zcds_crud (order_number, item_number, uom, quantity) 
  VALUES (:iv_order, :iv_item, :iv_uom, :iv_qty); 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD update_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  UPDATE zcds_crud 
  SET item_number = :iv_item, 
      uom         = :iv_uom, 
      quantity    = :iv_qty 
  WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD delete_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  DELETE FROM zcds_crud WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
ENDCLASS.

5.3 ABAP Report: Selection Screen 

REPORT zcrud_report_amdp. 
 
PARAMETERS: p_ord TYPE zcds_crud-order_number OBLIGATORY, 
            p_read  AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT abap_true, 
            p_crea  AS CHECKBOX, 
            p_upd   AS CHECKBOX, 
            p_del   AS CHECKBOX. 
 
PARAMETERS: p_item TYPE zcds_crud-item_number, 
            p_uom  TYPE zcds_crud-uom, 
            p_qty  TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
DATA: lt_data TYPE zcrud_procedure=>tt_type, 
      ls_data TYPE zcds_crud.

5.4 ABAP Report: Execution and CRUD Operations 

START-OF-SELECTION.

  CASE 'X'.
    WHEN rb_read.
      PERFORM read_data.
    WHEN rb_crt.
      PERFORM create_screen.
    WHEN rb_upd.
      PERFORM update_screen.
    WHEN rb_dlt.
      PERFORM delete_data.
  ENDCASE.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* READ MODE â€“ SHOW DATA IN ALV (Display Only)
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM read_data.

  zcrud_procedure=>read_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord
    IMPORTING it_data  = lt_data ).

  IF lt_data IS INITIAL.
    WRITE: / 'No record found'.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  CALL SCREEN 100.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* CREATE MODE â€“ EMPTY ALV WITH HEADERS (Editable)
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_screen.

  CLEAR lt_data.
  ls_data-order_number = p_ord.
  ls_data-item_number  = p_item.
  ls_data-uom          = p_uom.
  ls_data-quantity     = p_qty.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>insert_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity
      ).
*      WRITE: / 'Record created successfully.'.
      MESSAGE 'Record created successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx).
      WRITE: / 'Error creating record:', lx->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
  "Add empty row
*  APPEND INITIAL LINE TO lt_data.
  append ls_data to lt_data.

  CALL SCREEN 200.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* UPDATE MODE â€“ ORDER DISPLAY ONLY, OTHERS EDITABLE
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM update_screen.

  IF rb_upd = abap_true.
  zcrud_procedure=>read_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord
    IMPORTING it_data = lt_data
  ).

  IF lt_data IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE: 'No record found for update' type 'S'.
  ELSE.
    ls_data = lt_data[ 1 ].
    " Editable mode: overwrite with screen input if provided
    IF p_item IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-item_number = p_item.
    ENDIF.
    IF p_uom IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-uom = p_uom.
    ENDIF.
    IF p_qty IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-quantity = p_qty.
    ENDIF.

    TRY.
        zcrud_procedure=>update_data(
          EXPORTING
            iv_order = ls_data-order_number
            iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
            iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
            iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity
        ).
        MESSAGE 'Record updated successfully' TYPE 'S'.
      CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lxupd).
        MESSAGE 'Error updating record:' TYPE 'S'.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDIF.
ENDIF.

  CALL SCREEN 300.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* DELETE MODE
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM delete_data.

  zcrud_procedure=>delete_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord ).

  MESSAGE 'Record Deleted successfully' TYPE 'S'.

ENDFORM.


*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 100 â€“ READ MODE (DISPLAY ALV)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0100 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN100'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING i_structure_name = 'ZCDS_CRUD'
    CHANGING  it_outtab        = lt_data.

ENDMODULE.




*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 200 â€“ CREATE MODE (Editable)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0200 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN200'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING i_structure_name = 'ZCDS_CRUD'
              i_default   = 'X'
    CHANGING  it_outtab        = lt_data.

ENDMODULE.

MODULE user_command_0200 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

  READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data INDEX 1.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>insert_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity ).
      MESSAGE 'Record Created Successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx).
      MESSAGE lx->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.

  LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
ENDMODULE.


*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 300 â€“ UPDATE MODE (Order display only)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0300 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN300'.

  DATA lt_fieldcat TYPE lvc_t_fcat.
  DATA ls_fcat     TYPE lvc_s_fcat.

  "ITEM/UOM/QTY editable
  LOOP AT lt_data INTO ls_data.
  ENDLOOP.

  "Build field catalog
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'ORDER_NUMBER'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Order'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = ''.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'ITEM_NUMBER'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Item'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'UOM'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'UOM'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'QUANTITY'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Qty'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING
      is_layout       = VALUE lvc_s_layo( )
    CHANGING
      it_outtab       = lt_data
      it_fieldcatalog = lt_fieldcat.

ENDMODULE.

MODULE user_command_0300 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

  READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data INDEX 1.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>update_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity ).
      MESSAGE 'Record Updated Successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lxupd).
      MESSAGE lxupd->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.

  LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
ENDMODULE.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0100  INPUT
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*       text
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE user_command_0100 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

ENDMODULE.

7. CRUD Operation Outputs (Screenshots Section) 

7.1 READ Operation Output 

7.2 CREATE Operation Output 

 

 

7.3 UPDATE Operation Output 

 

 

7.4 DELETE Operation Output 

 

 

6. Conclusion 

This implementation demonstrates how to: 

  • Use AMDP classes to handle CRUD operations directly on HANA 
  • Separate data logic (AMDP) from presentation logic (ABAP report) 
  • Handle different CRUD modes efficiently 
  • Provide clear user messages for all operations 

This approach ensures performance, maintainability, and user-friendliness while working with SAP HANA and ABAP together, and it can be extended to other database-intensive operations following the same pattern.

entry.title: SAP CPQ - Make your beautiful Christmas Theme in your tenant
entry.content:
The holiday season is here, and what better way to spread festive cheer than by giving your SAP CPQ tenant a beautiful Christmas makeover? A themed interface not only adds a touch of joy but also creates a delightful experience for your users during this special time of year.

Why Customize Your SAP CPQ Theme?

SAP CPQ offers flexible branding options that allow you to personalize the look and feel of your tenant. By applying a Christmas theme, you can:

  • Enhance user engagement with a festive interface.
  • Reflect your companyâ€™s holiday spirit.
  • Create a memorable experience for customers and internal teams.

Steps to Create a Christmas Theme in SAP CPQ

1. Access Branding Settings

Navigate to Setup â†’ Administration â†’ UI Designâ†’Branding in your SAP CPQ tenant. This is where you can customize with your style sheet

/* --- Header Background Styling --- */
.christmas-theme {
    /* Set a dark background if desired, or keep original. */
    /* background-color: #0d1a26; */ 
    position: relative; /* Essential for positioning lights and snow */
    overflow: hidden; /* Important to keep snow/lights contained */
}

/* --- Christmas Lights Container --- */
.christmas-lights {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 20px; /* Adjust height for visibility */
    display: flex;
    justify-content: space-around; /* Distribute lights evenly */
    align-items: center;
    pointer-events: none; /* Allows clicks to pass through */
    z-index: 10; /* Make sure lights are on top of the header background */
}

/* --- Light Bulb Styling --- */
.light-bulb {
    width: 11px;
    height: 15px;
    border-radius: 50% / 80% 80% 20% 20%; /* Bulb shape */
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.7);
    animation: blink 1s infinite alternate; /* Simple blinking animation */
    position: relative;
    margin: 0 5px; /* Spacing between bulbs */
}

/* Add a "wire" to the bulb */
.light-bulb::before {
    content: '';
    position: absolute;
    top: -5px; /* Position above the bulb */
    left: 50%;
    transform: translateX(-50%);
    width: 5px;
    height: 5px;
    background-color: #333; /* Dark color for the wire */
}

/* --- Color Variations and Light Glow --- */
.light-bulb.red {
    background-color: #ff0000;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #ff0000;
}
.light-bulb.green {
    background-color: #94BF31;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #94BF31;
    animation-delay: 0.3s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.gold {
    background-color: #00ff34;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #00ff34;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.purple {
    background-color: #FF00FF;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #FF00FF;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.blue {
    background-color: #0000FF;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #0000FF;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.pink {
    background-color: #ff347b;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #ff347b;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}

/* Blinking Animation */
@keyframes blink {
    from { opacity: 1; }
    to { opacity: 0.5; }
}

/* --- Snowfall Effect Container --- */
.snowfall-effect {
    position: absolute;
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 100%;
    pointer-events: none;
    background-image: radial-gradient(white 1px, transparent 0),
                      radial-gradient(white 2px, transparent 0),
                      radial-gradient(white 3px, transparent 0);
    background-size: 50px 50px, 70px 70px, 90px 90px;
    animation: snowfall 10s linear infinite; /* Animation to move the snow down */
    z-index: 5; /* Below the lights */
}

/* Snowfall Animation */
@keyframes snowfall {
    from { background-position: 0 0, 0 0, 0 0; }
    to { background-position: 500px 500px, 500px 500px, 500px 500px; }
}

</div>
<script>
    $('.side-menu-toggle').click(function () {
        $("#wrap").toggleClass("side-menu-expanded");
        $('.side-menu-toggle').toggleClass('rotated-side-menu-toggle');

        // trigger tabdrop update on expanding/collapsing menu on quote pages
        if (document.location.pathname.indexOf('/quotation/') !== -1) {
            // timeout because of sidemenu animation
            setTimeout(function () {
                $(window).resize();
            }, 550)
        }
    });

    $('.list-header .sap-icon').click(function (event) {
        event.target.classList.toggle('rotated');
    });

    $('.list-header .sap-icon').on('keydown', function (event) {
        if (event.keyCode === 13) {
            event.target.classList.toggle('rotated');
        };
    });

    function encodeQueryStringParameter (key, value) {
        return encodeURIComponent(key) + '=' + encodeURIComponent(value);
    }

    $('#CatalogId').on('click', function (event) {
        var quoteId = sessionStorage.getItem("quoteId");

        if (quoteId && !isNaN(quoteId)) {
            var currentHref = $(this).attr('href');

            if (currentHref.endsWith("Catalogue/CategoryTree.aspx") != -1) {
                if (!currentHref.includes("quoteId")) {
                    var newHref = currentHref + "?" + encodeQueryStringParameter('quoteId', quoteId);
                    $(this).attr('href', newHref);
                }
            }
        }
    });
</script>

Pro Tips

  • Keep it professional: Avoid overly flashy designs that may distract users.
  • Maintain accessibility: Ensure color contrast meets accessibility standards.
  • Schedule a revert: Plan to switch back to your standard theme after the holidays.
